ayahs.text: The original Quran is preserved in the Preserved Tablet (Lawh Mahfuz) with Allah. This verse emphasizes the divine origin and eternal preservation of the Quran, ensuring that Allah's word remains uncorrupted and unchanged throughout time. The Preserved Tablet is also referred to by different names in various parts of the Quran, including Umm al-Kitab (Mother of the Book) in Surah Az-Zukhruf, Kitab Maknun (Hidden Book) in Surah Al-Waqi'ah, and Suhuf Mukarramah Marfu'ah Mutahharah (Honored Pages, Exalted and Purified) in Surah Abasa. This preservation guarantees that divine guidance remains accessible to humanity in its pure form, providing certainty and comfort to believers that they have access to authentic revelation.

This verse continues the theme of divine preservation, reiterating that the Quran is inscribed in the Preserved Tablet with Allah. The repetition emphasizes the critical importance of this truth - that the divine scripture is eternally safeguarded from any corruption or alteration. This preservation extends beyond mere textual integrity to encompass the spiritual and practical guidance contained within the Quran. The various names used for this divine repository throughout the Quran highlight different aspects of its sanctity and significance, reinforcing the concept that believers can have complete confidence in the authenticity and reliability of the divine message they follow.

The verse reaffirms the preservation of the Quran in the Lawh Mahfuz, continuing the emphasis on divine protection of the scripture. This preservation serves as a source of strength and confidence for believers, especially during times of trial and persecution when the authenticity of their faith might be questioned by others. The multiple references to this divine preservation throughout the Quran underscore its fundamental importance in Islamic theology. Believers can find comfort in knowing that their source of guidance has been divinely protected since its origin and will remain so until the end of time, ensuring that future generations will have access to the same pure revelation.

Every soul has a guardian appointed over it, indicating that no human being exists without divine oversight and protection. This verse establishes the concept of angelic guardianship over humanity, as further elaborated in other Quranic passages. In Surah Al-Infitar, it is explained that these are honorable recording angels who know everything humans do, while Surah Al-An'am mentions that Allah sends guardians over His servants. These angels serve multiple functions in human life - some are responsible for recording human deeds and maintaining a comprehensive record of all actions, while others are tasked with providing protection and guidance. This divine system ensures that every individual receives appropriate oversight and that their actions are properly documented for eventual accountability. The presence of these guardians demonstrates Allah's care and attention to each human being, regardless of their status or circumstances.

This verse reinforces the concept that every soul has appointed guardians, emphasizing the comprehensive nature of divine oversight. The system of angelic guardianship reflects Allah's perfect knowledge and justice, ensuring that no action goes unnoticed or unrecorded. These noble scribes, as described in other Quranic verses, maintain detailed records of human behavior, which will serve as evidence on the Day of Judgment. The presence of these guardians also provides comfort to believers, knowing that they are under divine protection and guidance. This angelic oversight serves as both a source of accountability, encouraging righteous behavior, and a source of security, knowing that Allah has appointed protectors for every individual. The multiplicity of angels assigned to each person demonstrates the importance Allah places on human life and the meticulous care with which divine justice operates.

The verse continues to emphasize that every soul has guardians, highlighting the universal nature of this divine arrangement. This comprehensive system of angelic oversight ensures that Allah's knowledge encompasses all human activities without exception. The guardians serve dual purposes - protection and recording - demonstrating Allah's mercy and justice working in harmony. For believers, this knowledge should inspire both gratitude for divine protection and mindfulness of their actions, knowing that everything is being recorded. The fact that these are described as honorable and noble angels indicates the dignity and importance Allah assigns to human beings, that such elevated creatures are appointed for their oversight. This arrangement also emphasizes personal responsibility, as individuals cannot claim ignorance of their accountability when they know their actions are being witnessed and recorded by appointed divine agents.

This verse describes the origin of seminal fluid, which emerges from between the backbone and the ribs. This refers to the anatomical understanding of human reproduction, where the male reproductive substance originates from the area between the spine and the ribs before reaching the specialized glands. This description demonstrates the Quran's precise knowledge of human biology and reproduction, providing insight into the divine wisdom behind human creation. The verse connects the physical process of reproduction to the broader themes of divine power and resurrection that permeate the surah. By highlighting the origins of human life from such humble beginnings, the verse prepares the ground for discussing Allah's power to recreate and resurrect, showing how the same divine power that initiates life can restore it after death.

Allah is certainly capable of returning the human being, demonstrating His power over life and death. The same Allah who created human beings from a drop of water has the complete ability to call them back to Himself whenever He wills. This verse establishes the certainty of death as a return to Allah and affirms the divine power of resurrection after death. The connection between initial creation and resurrection emphasizes that the same creative power that brought humans into existence can easily restore them to life after their demise. This truth provides comfort to believers facing mortality and serves as a reminder of accountability in the afterlife. The verse also reinforces the temporary nature of worldly life and the permanent nature of the relationship between the Creator and His creation, encouraging believers to prepare for their eventual return to Allah.

The verse reiterates Allah's power to return and resurrect human beings, emphasizing the certainty of this divine capability. The repetition underscores the fundamental importance of believing in resurrection and the afterlife, which forms a cornerstone of Islamic faith. This divine power over life and death provides the foundation for ultimate justice, ensuring that all human actions will face appropriate consequences in the hereafter. For believers, this knowledge brings both hope for eternal reward and motivation for righteous living. The verse connects the miracle of initial creation from a simple drop of fluid to the miracle of resurrection, showing that both are equally within Allah's power. This understanding helps believers maintain perspective on the temporary nature of worldly challenges and the eternal significance of spiritual preparation.

This verse continues the emphasis on Allah's power of resurrection, reinforcing the certainty that the same divine power that created humans can restore them after death. The connection between creation and resurrection serves as a logical proof for the possibility and certainty of the afterlife. This understanding provides believers with confidence in divine justice and the ultimate resolution of all earthly injustices. The verse also serves as a reminder of human dependence on Allah for both life and death, encouraging humility and gratitude. The power of resurrection demonstrates that death is not an end but a transition, and that the relationship between humans and their Creator extends beyond the boundaries of earthly existence into eternal accountability and reward.

The verse reaffirms Allah's capability to return and resurrect, continuing the theme of divine power over life and death. This repetition serves to firmly establish this truth in the minds of believers and to address any doubts about the possibility of resurrection. The emphasis on this divine attribute provides assurance that justice will ultimately prevail, as those who suffer in this world will find relief in the next, while those who cause suffering will face accountability. This knowledge encourages patience during trials and motivates continued righteous action despite temporary setbacks. The certainty of resurrection also emphasizes the importance of spiritual preparation and the cultivation of good deeds that will benefit individuals in the eternal life to come.

Allah swears by the earth that splits open, referring to the phenomenon where rain falls from the sky and causes vegetation to break through the earth's surface as it grows. This natural process serves as a powerful metaphor for resurrection, demonstrating how life emerges from apparent death and barrenness. The earth's ability to bring forth life after appearing lifeless provides a clear sign of Allah's power to resurrect the dead. This oath by the earth and its life-giving properties serves as a witness to the reality of resurrection and the afterlife. The cycle of plant life - from seed to growth to death to regrowth - mirrors the human journey from creation to death to resurrection, providing a natural proof for divine power over life and death.

The verse continues the oath by the earth that splits, emphasizing how both the heavens (through rain) and the earth (through vegetation) bear witness to divine power and the reality of resurrection. This natural testimony reinforces the themes of creation, death, and resurrection that run throughout the surah. The collaboration between heaven and earth in producing life demonstrates the integrated nature of Allah's creation and His power over all natural processes. This observable phenomenon provides believers with daily reminders of divine power and the possibility of resurrection. The splitting of the earth by vegetation serves as a sign that what appears impossible or highly unlikely can occur through divine will and power.

The Quran is not a matter of jest or frivolity but represents the ultimate truth. This verse emphasizes the serious and truthful nature of the Quran's message, distinguishing it from human entertainment or fabrication. As stated in Surah Bani Israil, the Quran was revealed with truth and came down as truth, establishing its divine origin and reliability. This declaration serves to counter any attempts to dismiss the Quran's teachings as mere stories or human invention. The serious nature of the Quran's message demands serious consideration and response from its readers. This truth encompasses all aspects of the Quran's content, including its teachings about resurrection, divine justice, and human accountability, which have been the focus of the preceding verses.

The verse reiterates that the Quran is not a jest, emphasizing the gravity and truthfulness of its message. This repetition serves to firmly establish the serious nature of divine revelation and the importance of treating it with appropriate reverence and consideration. The truth of the Quran extends to all its teachings, including the difficult concepts of resurrection and judgment that might seem incredible to some. By emphasizing that the Quran is revealed with truth and contains only truth, the verse encourages believers to have complete confidence in its guidance. This truth also implies that the warnings and promises contained in the Quran will certainly be fulfilled, making it essential for readers to take its message seriously and respond appropriately.

This verse continues to emphasize that the Quran is not frivolous but represents serious divine truth. The repetition underscores the critical importance of approaching the Quran with the proper attitude of respect and serious consideration. The truthful nature of the Quran means that its teachings about the afterlife, divine judgment, and human responsibility are not hypothetical scenarios but certain realities that will come to pass. This understanding should motivate believers to align their lives with Quranic guidance and prepare for the accountability described in its pages. The serious nature of the Quran also means that rejecting or ignoring its message carries serious consequences, while accepting and following it leads to eternal benefit and salvation.

Allah instructs the Prophet to give the disbelievers time and leave them in their condition for a while, demonstrating divine patience and mercy even toward those who reject the truth. This command was particularly relevant during the early Meccan period when believers faced severe persecution from the polytheists of Mecca. The instruction for patience appears repeatedly in early Meccan surahs, as Allah advised the Prophet not to rush in dealing with his opponents but to wait for divine timing. As mentioned in Surah Al-Ahqaf, the Prophet is instructed to be patient as the determined messengers before him were patient and not to seek haste in divine judgment. During this period, when the polytheists of Mecca had made life difficult for the believers, these verses provided comfort and consolation through the Prophet to the faithful community. They explained that Allah wished to give these people additional time for potential repentance, encouraging believers to be patient with the hardships they faced while waiting for Allah's final decision. This divine wisdom in granting respite demonstrates that even persistent opposition to truth is met with opportunities for redemption and reflection.
